question: What is the supreme law of the land?

What is an amendment?

options.text: a state's right to nullify federal law
the process of impeaching a president

question: What do we call the first ten amendments to the Constitution?
What is one right or freedom from the First Amendment?
How many amendments does the Constitution have?
What did the Declaration of Independence do?

options.text: said that the United States is free (from Great Britain)
established the first government of the United States

question: What are two rights in the Declaration of Independence?
What is freedom of religion?

options.text: You can practice any religion, or not practice a religion.
You must choose one of the government-approved religions.
You can only practice Christianity in the United States.
Religious practices are restricted to private homes.
All citizens must attend a religious service weekly.
The government decides which religions are permitted.
You can practice any religion if you pay a special tax.

question: What is the economic system in the United States?
What is the 'rule of law'?

options.text: No one is above the law.
Laws apply differently to different people.
The President makes all the laws.
Wealthy citizens can ignore certain laws.
Only Congress must follow the law.

question: Name one branch or part of the government.
What stops one branch of government from becoming too powerful?
Who is in charge of the executive branch?
Who makes federal laws?
What are the two parts of the U.S. Congress?

options.text: the Senate and the Supreme Court
the Federal Government and State Governments

question: How many U.S. Senators are there?
We elect a U.S. Senator for how many years?
Who is one of your state's U.S. Senators now?

options.text: Answers will vary based on state. [District of Columbia residents and residents of U.S. territories should answer that D.C. (or the territory where the applicant lives) has no U.S. Senators.]
All states have the same senators
Every state has only one senator
The governor also serves as senator
Senators are selected by the President

question: Under our Constitution, some powers belong to the federal government. What is one power of the federal government?
Under our Constitution, some powers belong to the states. What is one power of the states?
Who is the Governor of your state now?

options.text: Answers will vary. [District of Columbia residents should answer that D.C. does not have a Governor.]
All states have the same governor
Governors are appointed by the President
The Vice President serves as governor of all states
States are governed directly by Congress
Governors are appointed by the Supreme Court
The Speaker of the House appoints governors

question: What is the capital of your state?

options.text: Answers will vary. [District of Columbia residents should answer that D.C. is not a state and does not have a capital. Residents of U.S. territories should name the capital of the territory.]
All state capitals are in Washington D.C.
New York City is the capital of all states
State capitals are always the largest city in the state
The federal government chooses state capitals
The President designates all state capitals

question: What are the two major political parties in the United States?

What is the name of the Speaker of the House of Representatives now?
There are four amendments to the Constitution about who can vote. Describe one of them.

options.text: You don't have to pay (a poll tax) to vote.
Any citizen can vote. (Women and men can vote.)
A male citizen of any race (can vote).
Only people born in the United States can vote.
You must pass a literacy test to vote.
You must be at least 21 years old to vote.
You must own land to vote.

question: What is one responsibility that is only for United States citizens?

options.text: the right to vote in federal elections
the right to run for federal office
the right to obtain a U.S. passport
the right to become a government employee
the right to apply for federal grants
the right to serve on a federal jury

question: What do we show loyalty to when we say the Pledge of Allegiance?
What is one promise you make when you become a United States citizen?

options.text: give up loyalty to other countries
defend the Constitution and laws of the United States
obey the laws of the United States
serve in the U.S. military (if needed)
serve (do important work for) the nation (if needed)
be loyal to the United States
give up your previous citizenship forever
own a home within five years

question: How old do citizens have to be to vote for President?

options.text: any age if registered to vote

question: What are two ways that Americans can participate in their democracy?

options.text: give an elected official your opinion on an issue
publicly support or oppose an issue or policy

Who lived in America before the Europeans arrived?

options.text: No one lived in America before Europeans

question: What group of people was taken to America and sold as slaves?
Why did the colonists fight the British?

options.text: because of high taxes (taxation without representation)
because the British army stayed in their houses (boarding, quartering)
because they wanted to abolish slavery
because they wanted to form the United Nations
because they wanted to establish democracy in Britain
because Britain forced them to trade only with Britain

because they wanted to create the Constitution

question: What did the Emancipation Proclamation do?

options.text: freed slaves in the Confederate states

gave women the right to vote

granted citizenship to all former slaves
established the right to vote for all men

question: What did Susan B. Anthony do?

options.text: was the first female Supreme Court Justice

question: What major event happened on September 11, 2001, in the United States?

options.text: The first African American president was elected.
